item.title: Eric add a quote by Lewis Carroll
item.description: "She generally gave herself very good advice, (though she very seldom followed it)." -- Lewis Carroll

item.title: Eric add a quote by Bram Stoker
item.description: "I have always thought that a wild animal never looks so well as when some obstacle of pronounced durability is between us. A personal experience has intensified rather than diminished that idea." -- Bram Stoker

item.title: Eric add a quote by Edgar Allan Poe
item.description: "The best chess-player in Christendom may be little more than the best player of chess; but proficiency in whist implies capacity for success in all those more important undertakings where mind struggles with mind." -- Edgar Allan Poe

item.title: Eric add a quote by Jonathan Swift
item.description: "And he gave it for his opinion, "that whoever could make two ears of corn, or two blades of grass, to grow upon a spot of ground where only one grew before, would deserve better of mankind, and do more essential service to his country, than the whole race of politicians put together." -- Jonathan Swift

item.title: Eric add a quote by Bernard M. Baruch
item.description: "Be who you are and say what you feel, because those who mind don't matter, and those who matter don't mind." -- Bernard M. Baruch

item.title: Eric add a quote by Christopher Moore
item.description: "Boredom can be a lethal thing on a small island." -- Christopher Moore

item.title: Eric add a quote by Walt Whitman
item.description: "The art of art, the glory of expression and the sunshine of the light of letters, is simplicity." -- Walt Whitman

item.title: Eric add a quote by Toni Morrison
item.description: "For me, Art is the restoration of order. It may discuss all sort of terrible things, but there must be satisfaction at the end. A little bit of hunger, but also satisfaction." -- Toni Morrison

item.title: Eric add a quote by Charles Dickens
item.description: "There are only two styles of portrait painting: the serious and the smirk." -- Charles Dickens

item.title: Eric add a quote by Tom Stoppard
item.description: "Skill without imagination is craftsmanship and gives us many useful objects such as wickerwork picnic baskets. Imagination without skill gives us modern art." -- Tom Stoppard

item.title: Eric add a quote by Charlotte Brontë
item.description: "Dread remorse when you are tempted to err, Miss Eyre; remorse is the poison of life." -- Charlotte Brontë

item.title: Eric add a quote by John Steinbeck
item.description: "Power does not corrupt. Fear corrupts... perhaps the fear of a loss of power." -- John Steinbeck

item.title: Eric add a quote by Arthur Miller
item.description: "Maybe all one can do is hope to end up with the right regrets." -- Arthur Miller

item.title: Eric add a quote by Mark Twain
item.description: "A person that started in to carry a cat home by the tail was gitting knowledge that was always going to be useful to him, and warn't ever going to grow dim or doubtful." -- Mark Twain

item.title: Eric add a quote by Mark Twain
item.description: "All right, then, I'll go to hell." -- Mark Twain

item.title: Eric add a quote by Max Beerbohm
item.description: "You cannot make a man by standing a sheep on its hind-legs. But by standing a flock of sheep in that position you can make a crowd of men." -- Max Beerbohm

item.title: Eric add a quote by Herman Melville
item.description: "Is he mad? Anyway there's something on his mind, as sure as there must be something on a deck when it cracks." -- Herman Melville

item.title: Eric add a quote by F. Scott Fitzgerald
item.description: "They slipped briskly into an intimacy from which they never recovered." -- F. Scott Fitzgerald

item.title: Eric add a quote by Arthur Conan Doyle
item.description:
"Is there any point to which you would wish to draw my attention?'
'To the curious incident of the dog in the night-time.'
'The dog did nothing in the night-time.'
'That was the curious incident,' remarked Sherlock Holmes." -- Arthur Conan Doyle

item.title: Eric add a quote by Mark Haddon
item.description: "Prime numbers are what is left when you have taken all the patterns away. I think prime numbers are like life. They are very logical but you could never work out the rules, even if you spent all your time thinking about them." -- Mark Haddon

item.title: Eric add a quote by Charles Dickens
item.description: "She dotes on poetry, sir. She adores it; I may say that her whole soul and mind are wound up, and entwined with it. She has produced some delightful pieces, herself, sir. You may have met with her 'Ode to an Expiring Frog,' sir." -- Charles Dickens

item.title: Eric add a quote by Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
item.description: "Picnics are very dear to those who are in the first stage of the tender passion." -- Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
